short_doc: Represents a single read or write operation performed by a Proxy. ...

members.short_doc: The action being performed by this Operation. ...
members.name: action
members.doc: The action being performed by this Operation. Should be one of 'create', 'read', 'update' or 'destroy'.

members.name: batch
members.doc: The batch that this Operation is a part of.

members.short_doc: Function to execute when operation completed. ...
members.name: callback
filters
members.doc: Optional array of filter objects. Only applies to 'read' actions.

members.name: group
members.doc: Optional grouping configuration. Only applies to 'read' actions where grouping is desired.

members.name: grouper
members.doc: Optional grouping configuration. Only applies to 'read' actions where grouping is desired.

members.short_doc: The number of records to load. ...
members.name: limit
members.doc: The number of records to load. Used on 'read' actions when paging is being used.

members.short_doc: The Model that this Operation will be dealing with. ...
members.name: model
members.doc: The Model that this Operation will be dealing with. This configuration is required when defining any Operation. Since Operations take care of creating, updating, destroying and reading records, it needs access to the Model.

members.short_doc: The params send along with this operation. ...
members.name: params
members.doc: The params send along with this operation. These usually apply to a Server proxy if you are creating your own custom proxy,

members.short_doc: The records associated to this operation. ...
members.name: records
members.doc: The records associated to this operation. Before an operation starts, these are the records you are updating, creating, or destroying. After an operation is completed, a Proxy usually sets these records on the Operation to become the processed records. If you don't set these records on your operation in your proxy, then the getter will return the ones defined on the resultSet

members.short_doc: The request used for this Operation. ...
members.name: request
members.doc: The request used for this Operation. Operations don't usually care about Request and Response data, but in the ServerProxy and any of its subclasses they may be useful for further processing.

members.name: response
members.doc: The response that was gotten from the server if there was one.

members.name: sorters
members.doc: Optional array of sorter objects. Only applies to 'read' actions.

members.name: start
members.doc: The start index (offset), used in paging when running a 'read' action.

members.short_doc: True if this Operation is to be executed synchronously. ...
members.name: synchronous
members.doc: True if this Operation is to be executed synchronously. This property is inspected by a Batch to see if a series of Operations can be executed in parallel or not.

members.name: withCredentials
members.doc: This field is necessary when using cross-origin resource sharing.

members.short_doc: Property tracking the completion status of this Operation. ...
members.name: complete
members.doc: Property tracking the completion status of this Operation. Use isComplete.

members.short_doc: The error object passed when setException was called. ...
members.name: error
members.doc: The error object passed when setException was called. This could be any object or primitive.

members.short_doc: Property tracking the exception status of this Operation. ...
members.name: exception
members.doc: Property tracking the exception status of this Operation. Use hasException and see getError.

members.short_doc: Property tracking the run status of this Operation. ...
members.name: running
members.doc: Property tracking the run status of this Operation. Use isRunning.

members.short_doc: Get the reference to the current class from which this object was instantiated. ...
members.name: self
members.doc:
Get the reference to the current class from which this object was instantiated. Unlike statics, this.self is scope-dependent and it's meant to be used for dynamic inheritance. See statics for a detailed comparison

Ext.define('My.Cat', {
    statics: {
        speciesName: 'Cat' // My.Cat.speciesName = 'Cat'
    },

    constructor: function() {
        alert(this.self.speciesName); // dependent on 'this'
    },

    clone: function() {
        return new this.self();
    }
});


Ext.define('My.SnowLeopard', {
    extend: 'My.Cat',
    statics: {
        speciesName: 'Snow Leopard'         // My.SnowLeopard.speciesName = 'Snow Leopard'
    }
});

var cat = new My.Cat();                     // alerts 'Cat'
var snowLeopard = new My.SnowLeopard();     // alerts 'Snow Leopard'

var clone = snowLeopard.clone();
alert(Ext.getClassName(clone));             // alerts 'My.SnowLeopard'

members.short_doc: Property tracking the start status of this Operation. ...
members.name: started
members.doc: Property tracking the start status of this Operation. Use isStarted.

members.short_doc: Property tracking whether the Operation was successful or not. ...
members.name: success
members.doc: Property tracking whether the Operation was successful or not. This starts as undefined and is set to true or false by the Proxy that is executing the Operation. It is also set to false by setException. Use wasSuccessful to query success status.

members.short_doc: Checks whether this operation should cause writing to occur. ...

return.doc: Whether the operation should cause a write to occur.
return.name: return

members.name: allowWrite
members.doc: Checks whether this operation should cause writing to occur.

members.short_doc:
Call the original method that was previously overridden with override,

This method is deprecated as callParent does ...

params.doc: The arguments, either an array or the arguments object from the current method, for example: this.callOverridden(arguments)
params.name: args

return.doc: Returns the result of calling the overridden method
return.name: return

members.name: callOverridden
members.doc:
Call the original method that was previously overridden with override,

This method is deprecated as callParent does the same thing.

Ext.define('My.Cat', {
    constructor: function() {
        alert("I'm a cat!");
    }
});

My.Cat.override({
    constructor: function() {
        alert("I'm going to be a cat!");

        var instance = this.callOverridden();

        alert("Meeeeoooowwww");

        return instance;
    }
});

var kitty = new My.Cat(); // alerts "I'm going to be a cat!"
                          // alerts "I'm a cat!"
                          // alerts "Meeeeoooowwww"

members.short_doc: Call the "parent" method of the current method. ...

params.doc: The arguments, either an array or the arguments object from the current method, for example: this.callParent(arguments)
params.name: args

return.doc: Returns the result of calling the parent method
return.name: return

members.name: callParent
members.doc:
Call the "parent" method of the current method. That is the method previously overridden by derivation or by an override (see Ext.define).

 Ext.define('My.Base', {
     constructor: function (x) {
         this.x = x;
     },

     statics: {
         method: function (x) {
             return x;
         }
     }
 });

 Ext.define('My.Derived', {
     extend: 'My.Base',

     constructor: function () {
         this.callParent([21]);
     }
 });

 var obj = new My.Derived();

 alert(obj.x);  // alerts 21

This can be used with an override as follows:

 Ext.define('My.DerivedOverride', {
     override: 'My.Derived',

     constructor: function (x) {
         this.callParent([x*2]); // calls original My.Derived constructor
     }
 });

 var obj = new My.Derived();

 alert(obj.x);  // now alerts 42

This also works with static methods.

 Ext.define('My.Derived2', {
     extend: 'My.Base',

     statics: {
         method: function (x) {
             return this.callParent([x*2]); // calls My.Base.method
         }
     }
 });

 alert(My.Base.method(10));     // alerts 10
 alert(My.Derived2.method(10)); // alerts 20

Lastly, it also works with overridden static methods.

 Ext.define('My.Derived2Override', {
     override: 'My.Derived2',

     statics: {
         method: function (x) {
             return this.callParent([x*2]); // calls My.Derived2.method
         }
     }
 });

 alert(My.Derived2.method(10)); // now alerts 40

To override a method and replace it and also call the superclass method, use callSuper. This is often done to patch a method to fix a bug.

members.short_doc:
This method is used by an override to call the superclass method but bypass any
overridden method. ...

params.doc: The arguments, either an array or the arguments object from the current method, for example: this.callSuper(arguments)
params.name: args

return.doc: Returns the result of calling the superclass method
return.name: return

members.name: callSuper
members.doc:
This method is used by an override to call the superclass method but bypass any overridden method. This is often done to "patch" a method that contains a bug but for whatever reason cannot be fixed directly.

Consider:

 Ext.define('Ext.some.Class', {
     method: function () {
         console.log('Good');
     }
 });

 Ext.define('Ext.some.DerivedClass', {
     method: function () {
         console.log('Bad');

         // ... logic but with a bug ...

         this.callParent();
     }
 });

To patch the bug in DerivedClass.method, the typical solution is to create an override:

 Ext.define('App.paches.DerivedClass', {
     override: 'Ext.some.DerivedClass',

     method: function () {
         console.log('Fixed');

         // ... logic but with bug fixed ...

         this.callSuper();
     }
 });

The patch method cannot use callParent to call the superclass method since that would call the overridden method containing the bug. In other words, the above patch would only produce "Fixed" then "Good" in the console log, whereas, using callParent would produce "Fixed" then "Bad" then "Good".

members.short_doc: Returns the error string or object that was set using setException. ...
members.name: getError
members.doc: Returns the error string or object that was set using setException.

members.short_doc: Returns the initial configuration passed to constructor. ...

params.doc: When supplied, value for particular configuration option is returned, otherwise the full config object is returned.
params.name: name

members.name: getInitialConfig
members.doc: Returns the initial configuration passed to constructor.
Returns the value of node.
members.name: getNode

members.doc: Returns the value of page.
members.name: getPage

members.doc: Returns the value of url.
members.name: getUrl

members.short_doc: Returns true if this Operation encountered an exception (see also getError). ...
members.name: hasException
members.doc: Returns true if this Operation encountered an exception (see also getError).

return.doc: mixins The mixin prototypes as key - value pairs
return.name: return

members.name: initConfig
members.doc:
Initialize configuration for this class. a typical example:

Ext.define('My.awesome.Class', {
    // The default config
    config: {
        name: 'Awesome',
        isAwesome: true
    },

    constructor: function(config) {
        this.initConfig(config);
    }
});

var awesome = new My.awesome.Class({
    name: 'Super Awesome'
});

alert(awesome.getName()); // 'Super Awesome'

members.short_doc: Returns true if the Operation has been completed ...
members.name: isComplete
members.doc: Returns true if the Operation has been completed

members.short_doc: Returns true if the Operation has been started but has not yet completed. ...

return.doc: true if the Operation is currently running
return.name: return

members.name: isRunning
members.doc: Returns true if the Operation has been started but has not yet completed.

members.short_doc: Returns true if the Operation has been started. ...
members.name: isStarted
members.doc: Returns true if the Operation has been started. Note that the Operation may have started AND completed, see isRunning to test if the Operation is currently running.

members.short_doc: Marks the Operation as having experienced an exception. ...
members.name: setException
members.doc: Marks the Operation as having experienced an exception. Can be supplied with an option error message/object.
Sets the value of node.
members.name: setNode

members.doc: Sets the value of page.
members.name: setPage

members.doc: Sets the value of url.
members.name: setUrl

members.short_doc: Get the reference to the class from which this object was instantiated. ...
members.name: statics
members.doc:
Get the reference to the class from which this object was instantiated. Note that unlike self, this.statics() is scope-independent and it always returns the class from which it was called, regardless of what this points to during run-time

Ext.define('My.Cat', {
    statics: {
        totalCreated: 0,
        speciesName: 'Cat' // My.Cat.speciesName = 'Cat'
    },

    constructor: function() {
        var statics = this.statics();

        alert(statics.speciesName);     // always equals to 'Cat' no matter what 'this' refers to
                                        // equivalent to: My.Cat.speciesName

        alert(this.self.speciesName);   // dependent on 'this'

        statics.totalCreated++;
    },

    clone: function() {
        var cloned = new this.self();                    // dependent on 'this'

        cloned.groupName = this.statics().speciesName;   // equivalent to: My.Cat.speciesName

        return cloned;
    }
});


Ext.define('My.SnowLeopard', {
    extend: 'My.Cat',

    statics: {
        speciesName: 'Snow Leopard'     // My.SnowLeopard.speciesName = 'Snow Leopard'
    },

    constructor: function() {
        this.callParent();
    }
});

var cat = new My.Cat();                 // alerts 'Cat', then alerts 'Cat'

var snowLeopard = new My.SnowLeopard(); // alerts 'Cat', then alerts 'Snow Leopard'

var clone = snowLeopard.clone();
alert(Ext.getClassName(clone));         // alerts 'My.SnowLeopard'
alert(clone.groupName);                 // alerts 'Cat'

alert(My.Cat.totalCreated);             // alerts 3

members.short_doc: Returns true if the Operation has completed and was successful ...
members.name: wasSuccessful
members.doc: Returns true if the Operation has completed and was successful

members.short_doc: Add methods / properties to the prototype of this class. ...
members.name: addMembers
members.doc:
Add methods / properties to the prototype of this class.

Ext.define('My.awesome.Cat', {
    constructor: function() {
        // ...
    }
});

 My.awesome.Cat.addMembers({
     meow: function() {
        alert('Meowww...');
     }
 });

 var kitty = new My.awesome.Cat();
 kitty.meow();

members.short_doc: Add / override static properties of this class. ...
members.name: addStatics
members.doc:
Add / override static properties of this class.

Ext.define('My.cool.Class', {
    // this.se
});

My.cool.Class.addStatics({
    someProperty: 'someValue',      // My.cool.Class.someProperty = 'someValue'
    method1: function() {  },    // My.cool.Class.method1 = function() { ... };
    method2: function() {  }     // My.cool.Class.method2 = function() { ... };
});

members.short_doc: Borrow another class' members to the prototype of this class. ...

params.doc: The names of the members to borrow
params.name: members

members.name: borrow
members.doc:
Borrow another class' members to the prototype of this class.

Ext.define('Bank', {
    money: '$$$',
    printMoney: function() {
        alert('$$$$$$$');
    }
});

Ext.define('Thief', {
    // ...
});

Thief.borrow(Bank, ['money', 'printMoney']);

var steve = new Thief();

alert(steve.money); // alerts '$$$'
steve.printMoney(); // alerts '$$$$$$$'

members.short_doc: Create a new instance of this Class. ...
members.name: create
members.doc:
Create a new instance of this Class.

Ext.define('My.cool.Class', {
    // ...
});

My.cool.Class.create({
    someConfig: true
});

All parameters are passed to the constructor of the class.

members.short_doc: Create aliases for existing prototype methods. ...

params.doc: The new method name, or an object to set multiple aliases. See flexSetter
params.name: alias

members.name: createAlias
members.doc:
Create aliases for existing prototype methods. Example:

Ext.define('My.cool.Class', {
    method1: function() {  },
    method2: function() {  }
});

var test = new My.cool.Class();

My.cool.Class.createAlias({
    method3: 'method1',
    method4: 'method2'
});

test.method3(); // test.method1()

My.cool.Class.createAlias('method5', 'method3');

test.method5(); // test.method3() -> test.method1()

members.short_doc: Get the current class' name in string format. ...
members.name: getName
members.doc:
Get the current class' name in string format.

Ext.define('My.cool.Class', {
    constructor: function() {
        alert(this.self.getName()); // alerts 'My.cool.Class'
    }
});

My.cool.Class.getName(); // 'My.cool.Class'

members.short_doc: Used internally by the mixins pre-processor ...
members.name: mixin

params.doc: The properties to add to this class. This should be specified as an object literal containing one or more properties.
params.name: members

members.name: override
members.doc:
Override members of this class. Overridden methods can be invoked via callParent.

Ext.define('My.Cat', {
    constructor: function() {
        alert("I'm a cat!");
    }
});

My.Cat.override({
    constructor: function() {
        alert("I'm going to be a cat!");

        var instance = this.callParent(arguments);

        alert("Meeeeoooowwww");

        return instance;
    }
});

var kitty = new My.Cat(); // alerts "I'm going to be a cat!"
                          // alerts "I'm a cat!"
                          // alerts "Meeeeoooowwww"

As of 2.1, direct use of this method is deprecated. Use Ext.define instead:

Ext.define('My.CatOverride', {
    override: 'My.Cat',

    constructor: function() {
        alert("I'm going to be a cat!");

        var instance = this.callParent(arguments);

        alert("Meeeeoooowwww");

        return instance;
    }
});

The above accomplishes the same result but can be managed by the Ext.Loader which can properly order the override and its target class and the build process can determine whether the override is needed based on the required state of the target class (My.Cat).

doc:
Represents a single read or write operation performed by a Proxy. Operation objects are used to enable communication between Stores and Proxies. Application developers should rarely need to interact with Operation objects directly.

Note that when you define an Operation directly, you need to specify at least the model configuration.

Several Operations can be batched together in a batch.
name: Ext.data.Operation
